Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I stared at my laptop screen, heart pounding as error logs scrolled by. The critical service was buckling under load, and the traces pointed straight to the functions I’d merged this morning. My team was counting on me to fix it—fast. I knew I had to write clean, maintainable code, not just a quick patch, or we’d be in the same mess tomorrow. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: today was Election Day, and the polling station would close in fifteen minutes. I rushed over, only to be told by the official that my registration had a mismatch. If I wanted my vote to count, I had to fill out a provisional ballot form—right now, before the doors closed in ten minutes. My mind raced. My team needed me online, but my civic duty was right here, in my hands. I felt torn, the weight of both responsibilities pressing down, knowing I couldn’t fully meet the expectations of either role at this moment.
